entry.title: Re: EWM diff. analyzer: correct. of Q2 stock not triggeri...
entry.content:
Please see SAP-KBA "3608937 - Unable to enter Reason for Movement in Physical Inventory - SAP for Me" ...

Extract :
"Cause
In the EWM standard solution where postings from the Difference Analyzer are performed using movement type 711/712, the reason is hard coded as 'Inventory'. Hence there is no provision for the user to enter a custom reason for movement.

Resolution
The BAdI /SCWM/EX_ERP_GOODSMVT_EXT can be used to change the material document to be posted in ERP by providing a customer-specific movement type and Reason for Movement."

Hope this helps

Kind regards

Nic T.

entry.title: BI2025: Side-by-Side Migration
entry.content:
This is follow up on the migration topic to BI2025 from my blog: BI2025: Side-by-Side Migration vs. In-Place Update

Lets discuss what activities need to be planned to move to BI2025 if you choose side-by-side approach and also what kind of resource could be helpful to plan the migration/update.

Migrating from SAP BusinessObjects BI4.3 to BI2025 involves several strategic steps to ensure a smooth transition the newer platform. Based on resource availability and internal processes following major activities could be considered:

  1. Pre-Migration Planning
  2. Content Cleanup
  3. BIP 2025 deployment
  4. Content promotion
  5. Testing and Validation
  6. Training & Documentation

We will now take a detailed look at these activities.

1 . Pre-Migration Planning

  • Conduct a full assessment of your current BI 4.3 environment, including hardware, software, and system architecture. Consider to plan  following tasks:

1. 1 Environment Inventory

  • Task: Document the hardware and software components of your current BI 4.3 environment.
  • Details:
    • List all servers and their specifications (CPU, RAM, OS Version).
    • List all installed software middlwares and  databases, SDK-Applications.
    • Review all integration points with other systems, user authentification methods and used SSOs
    • Document network configurations, including firewalls, load balancers, and network topology.

You can use SAP BI Platform Support Tool to get overview of current used applications, number of reports, middlware and data base versions. Please refer to KBA 2407767 - SAP BI Platform Support Tool

Also Auditing reports are quite helpful to get overview of current system and content usage.

Please refer to following resources: SAP KBA 2456458 - Auditing in SAP BI Platform 4.x  and additional blogs about auditing, with sample reports:

  • Auditing Solution Update for SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform 4.3 +

Verify the compatibility of the new version with your current operating systems, databases, and SDK-application. Please check latest  PAM version KBA 1338845 - How to find Product Availability Matrix (PAM) / Supported Platforms Documentation for SAP BusinessObjects products?

Review features which are removed or deprecated in BI2025 and plan migration to alternative solutions.

  • Please see KBA 3560025 - Which products and features are removed in SAP BusinessObjects BI platform 2025.
  • 3582341 - FAQ on SAP BusinessObjects 2025 [BI 2025]
  • For deprecated features

Component

Go to solution

Blog

Lumira Discovery

SAP Analytics Cloud - Web Intelligence

Accelerate your move from SAP Lumira Designer to SAP Analytics Cloud

Crystal Reports for Enterprise

Crystal Reports - Web Intelligence

Moving from Crystal Reports for Enterprise to Crystal Reports

Analysis for OLAP

SAP Analytics Cloud

SAP-BusinessObjects Analysis Edition For Olap Alternatives

Live Office

SAP Analysis for Microsoft Office

Web Intelligence Document OData Access (4.3 SP2)

SAP BusinessObjects Live Office Alternatives

SAP BusinessObjects Mobile

Web browser on mobile devices

Web Intelligence Document eXtract (WIDX)

SAP BusinessObjects Mobile alternatives

Universe Design Tool (and .unv)

Information Design Tool (and .unx)

Unv is dead long live-unx 

Multi-source universes and associated connectivity

Data blending in Web Intelligence or at the DB level

BusinessObjects Multi source Universes Alternatives

Subversion as a bundled Version Management repository

Git or Github integration

SAP KBAs: 3581196 and 3335429 

1.2 User and License Assessment

  • Task: Evaluate the user base and current used licenses
  • Details:
    • List all active and inactive users.
    • Document the types of licenses currently in use.
    • Consider to create new licence keys for BI2025
  • KBAs:
    • 2251998 - How to generate license keys for SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence
    • 2282189 - New license keys required for 4.3/2025(and later)

Task 1.3 Backup and Recovery Assessment

  • Task: Assess the current backup and recovery procedures.
  • Details:
    • Check current backup methodology.
    • You will need a backup of Central Management Server (CMS) database & File Store, any Web Appserver configuration files, Webapps and customizations, and if SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform is on Virtual Machine, then it is advisable to take a snapshot of the machine.
    • Verify the integrity and restorability of backups.
    • Ensure that backups cover all critical data and configurations before performing update
  • KBAs:
    • 2306146 - Disaster recovery backup and restore best practices for restoring
    • 1275068 - Backup & Restore XI 3.1 / BI 4.x from one environment to another [video]

2. Content Cleanup

It would be good idea to perform some system clean up activities to reduce system foot print in CMS DB and FRS and also get rid off the obsolete or unused objects.

2.1. Obsolete Reporting Tools

  • Task: Review content used in BI4.3.
  • Details:
    • Based on analysis performed earlier define the strategy for outdated reporting tools/content (such as legacy Crystal Reports and Analysis for OLAP), decide whether to replace them with new solutions or remove them.
    • Archive obsolete content, if necessary. You can use LCM_BIAR files to create back-ups.
    • Remove or consolidate reports that are redundant or unused to streamline the migration process. Refer to SAP KBA 2464908 - SAP BI Promotion Management Best Practices [LCM]

Task 2.2 Consistency check

  • Task: Verify object consitency between the FRS and CMS database.
  • Details:
    • The inconsistencies can occur after disaster recovery, a network failure during a database write, content insert or update.
    • Run a Repository Diagnostics Scan (Reposcan) on Source (and on Target, after migration). Use both CMS and FRS: Scan & Repair options in the Source Environment.
  • KBAs and RDT Resources:
    • How to use the Repository Diagnostic Tool
    • 1689163 - How to use the Repository Diagnostic Tool (aka reposcan) in BI 4.x - for WINDOWS
    • 1752397 - How to use the Repository Diagnostic Tool (aka reposcan) in BI 4.x - for Unix / Linux,
    • 2306600 - How to resolve "The object has a missing or invalid Submitter Object ID." inconsistency after a CMS database migration
    • 1695971 - Repository Diagnostic Tool (reposcan) shows more file inconsistencies after the repair
    • 1267338 - How to use Repository Diagnostic Tool (reposcan)

3. BIP 2025 deployment

Task 3.1: Hardware and Network Preparation

  • Task: Ensure that your infrastructure meets BI2025‚Äôs technical requirements including hardware, operating system, and networking specifications.
  • Details:
    • Consider to check BI2025 PAM to verify if all prerequisites met
    • Align on network requirements and firewalls rules requierd for new enviroment. Please refer to KBA 2276646 - Firewall considerations for BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform 4.x (Servers and Clients)

For example, in PAM you can find information on supported in BI2025 operating systems and web application servers:

 

Provider NameNameMinimum Supported versionLatest
certified version		Supported
since		Notes

 

Tomcat9.x9.xBI 2025

Certified for SAP Machine (Java 17). As free open-source third-party web application server, SAP recommends you contact a qualified third-party vendor or consultant for performance tuning, security related issues and load balancer configurations (see SAP KBA 2280098). Please check KBA 2112338 for bundled tomcat and JVM version

BI 2025 is only supported on Windows and Linux operating systems and the Solaris and AIX support is removed.
With the GA release, BI 2025 is only supported on Tomcat Application Server, more importantly SAP NetWeaver application server support is removed. And other application servers certification is planned for future.

Next important topic is also BIP Add-ons.

‚ÄãBI2025 requires new Lumira Add-on - SAP Lumira Designer 2025, which is currently planned to be released in Q12026:
 
Analysis for Office Add-On.
‚ÄãBI2025 requires at least Analysis for Office SP26 installer.
‚ÄãFurthermore, additional improvement planned for AO 2.8 SP28  related to the SNC and the OpenID usage for the BIP Logon:
  • 3631157 - AO: BIP Logon via OpenID - Implemented possibility to use embedded browser
  • 3645976 - AO: BIP - Logon User is not available when using OpenID authentication
  • 3667319 - AO scheduling issues after upgrading server add-on to 2.8.26/27

4. Content promotion

Next we will take a look on activities related to content migration.

4.1 Target System Server Configuration

  • Task: Adjust setting realted to the promotion execution.
  • Details:
  •  Required Running Services
    • Core Services (Must Run):
    • Central Management Server (CMS)
    • Input File Repository Server (FRS)
    • Output File Repository Server (FRS)
    • Adaptive Job Server (AJS) with increased heap
    • Adaptive Processing Server (APS) with LCM services
    • Crystal Reports Application Server (RAS)
    • Connection Server
  • Memory Configuration:
    • Configure Promotion Management Service APS heap size to handle large content imports - minimum 15GB for bulk migrations. Set Java heap parameters in CMC > Servers > APS Properties > Command Line Arguments: -javaargs -Xmx15g or higher 
    • Increase AJS heap size to minimum 15GB for large-scale promotions. Configure in CMC > Servers > AJS Properties > Command Line Arguments: -javaargs -Xmx15g
  • System Settings
    • Disable auditing on target system during migration
    • Disable monitoring in CMC > Monitoring Application
    • Disable Platform Search/indexing to improve performance
    • Configure adequate temporary space - minimum 2.5x FRS size
  • Turn OFF rollback on target server for large data imports to improve performance
  • Disable firewalls/antivirus temporarily during migration if possible 
  • Authentication Settings
    • Configure external authentication on target but do NOT import groups initially
    • Disable authentication temporarily during bulk user/group migration for better performance
    • Re-enable authentication after user migration completion

4.2 Promotion Tool Selection

In next step you need to decide which of two available for content promotion tools is more suitable for your landscape/team. You can select between Promotion Management Wizard (PMW) and Command Line Interface (CLI). The table below summarise the feature for these tools:

 
Feature
PMW (Promotion Management Wizard)CLI (Command Line Interface)
Tool TypeGUI-based promotion toolCommand-line based tool
User InterfaceGraphical wizard interface with step-by-step guidanceText-based commands requiring syntax knowledge
Ease of UseUser-friendly for non-technical usersRequires technical expertise and command knowledge
Automation CapabilityLimited automation, primarily manual wizard stepsHigh automation potential through scripting
Batch OperationsSupports batch promotion of multiple objectsExcellent for bulk operations and scripting
Error HandlingVisual error messages and guided troubleshootingDetailed error logs but requires interpretation
Learning CurveLow - intuitive wizard-driven processHigh - requires command syntax and parameter knowledge
SchedulingManual execution through GUICan be scheduled via system schedulers
LoggingBuilt-in logging with visual feedbackComprehensive command-line logging
Remote ExecutionRequires GUI access to serverCan be executed remotely via SSH/terminal
Scripting SupportNo native scripting capabilityFull scripting and automation support
PerformanceGood for small to medium promotionsBetter performance for large-scale operations

The choice ultimately depends on your team's technical capabilities, automation requirements, and the specific nature of your promotion scenarios. Many organizations benefit from using both tools for different use cases within their BI platform management strategy. For example, for large-scale migrations:

  1. Use PMW for initial bulk content migration (users, groups, dependencies)
  2. Switch to CLI for large content in public/favourite folders or delta promotions and ongoing maintenance
  3. Use CLI for promoting instances and objects created after initial migration

Check out the Promotion Management best practices SAP KBAs:

  • 2464908 - SAP BI Promotion Management Best Practices [LCM]
  • 1969259 - LCMCLI Best Practices - How to promote thousands of objects in BI Platform using command line?
  • KBA 2464908, 2531264 - Best Practices for Promotion Management Wizard (PMW)
  •  SAP BI Pattern Book on Promotion
  • 3663096 - How to promote object or folder security but not content using the PMW tool when performing bulk content migration?

4.3 Phased Promotion Approach

For large deployment would make sense to split whole promotion in multiple phases. Below you will find recommended sequins for such aproach.

Phase 1: Security and Users.

  • Migrate user groups and users without dependencies
  • Include user artifacts (Inboxes, Favorites Folders, Personal Categories)
  • Validate user authentication and group memberships

Phase 2: Dependencies

  • Migrate Access Levels, Applications, Business Views, Calendars, Connections
  • Migrate Universes (UNX only), Data Source References, Events

Phase 3: Content Migration

  • Migrate public folders and content
  • Use selective content promotion in chunks for large repositories
  • For bulk operations, use LCM CLI with multiple queries capability

Phase 4: Security Application (Optional)

  • Apply object security using PMW by selecting objects at folder hierarchy endpoints
  • Consider using CLI for security replication following KBA 3663096 patterns

5. Testing and Validation

  • Task: Perform technical and functional testing.
  • Details:
    • Perform compatibility test and verify the functionality of all migrated assets on the new platform to ensure they work as intended.
    • Performance Testing: Conduct load testing to evaluate the performance of the BI2025 system under typical and peak conditionsUser Acceptance Testing (UAT): Engage business users in testing to validate usability and functionality from an end-user perspective.

6. Training & Documentation

  • Task: Consider to organize the trainings for end users and update the documentation
  • Details:
    • User Training: Provide comprehensive training sessions for users to acquaint them with new features and interfaces in BI2025.
    • Updated Documentation: Create and distribute updated documentation reflecting changes and new functionalities in the BI2025 environment.

I tried to provide some initial guides for migration to BI2025. The tasks can vary based on landscape complexity and available resource but general approach stays the same. 

Please also consider to check SAP Premium Engagement: A service roadmap for SAC, S/4 Embedded Analytics, Business Objects and Planning  for some details on SAP‚Äôs Center of Expertise (COE) for Analytics, Planning, and Consolidation and how we helping around analytic topics.

entry.title: ABAP Proxy generation support with SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

ABAP Proxies are one of the most widely used integration technologies in SAP landscapes. For years, they have been central to PI/PO-based integrations. Now, with the availability of ABAP Proxy support in SAP Integration Suite, customers can extend this capability to the cloud, accelerating their migration from PI/PO to Integration Suite. This closes an important gap for organizations transitioning from SAP Process Integration (PI/PO) to SAP Integration Suite .

This blog provides a technical overview and step-by-step setup guide for enabling generation of ABAP Proxies with Integration Suite.

What Are ABAP Proxies?

  • ABAP Proxies are generated classes in the SAP ABAP system based on service interfaces defined in the Enterprise Service Repository (ESR).

  • They allow ABAP developers to call or expose services without dealing with low-level communication protocols.

  • Proxies are commonly used for synchronous/asynchronous service calls, typically via SOAP adapters in PI/PO.

Why ABAP Proxy Support in SAP Integration Suite Matters?

Until recently, ABAP proxies were heavily tied to on-premise PI/PO middleware. With many customers moving their integration  to the cloud, there was a strong demand for equivalent support in Integration Suite.

Key benefits of the new support include:

  • Cloud-first Enablement ‚Äì Seamlessly connect SAP backends to Integration Suite using proxies.
  • Reuse of Existing Investments ‚Äì No need to redesign all integration scenarios; existing service interfaces can still be leveraged.
  • Simplified Migration from PI/PO ‚Äì Reduces the complexity of moving from legacy middleware to cloud-based integration.
  • Standardized Integration ‚Äì Continue using ESR artifacts and ABAP proxies as standardized communication interfaces.

Prerequisites

  • SAP Integration Suite tenant is active.
  • Connectivity between SAP backend and Integration Suite (HTTPS) is enabled.
  • Certificates (for mutual TLS if required) are exchanged.
  • Service interface meant for proxy generation must already be present/imported inside an Integration Package of the  SAP Integration Suite tenant
  • You've a user with the role  AuthGroup_IntegrationDeveloper assigned.

Connectivity between SAP backend and Integration Suite

For ABAP Proxy to Integration Suite, the standard practice is to configure an SM59 destination of type G.

SM59 Destination Configuration (Type G) :

Configuration Steps in SM59 (Type G)

Go to Transaction SM59

Choose HTTP Connections to External Server.

Create a new destination  or Open the existing Destination with name SAP_PROXY_ESR 

Technical Settings

  • Target Host: The host name of Integration Suite tenant(Navigate to BTP Cockpit  Instances and Subscriptions  < your instance for Service Process Integration Runtime with api Plan> View Credentials (in JSON format) and copy the url(without https://)  Note : Do not use the clientId and client secret from the Service Key instance

  • Service No.: 443 (for HTTPS).
  • Path Prefix: Enter the following : /rest/api/v1/workspace/sproxy 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Logon & Security

  • Choose Basic Authentication
  • Enter the credentials of the Technical user  with role AuthGroup_IntegrationDeveloper assigned and created with Default Identity Provider
  • Security Options
    • Select SSL Active
    • Import CPI‚Äôs Server certificate into transaction STRUST (SSL Client ‚Üí Standard).
    • Assign it to the relevant SSL Client PSE so that HTTPS trust is established

  • Save the changes and Perform Connection Test. Successful Connection Test result in HTTP 200 Ok Response .

 

 

 

 

 

 

Procedure to Generate ABAP Proxy

  • Log into the SAP ABAP backend system (ECC or S/4HANA).
  • Run transaction SPROXY.
    • This transaction allows browsing and generating proxies from  Service Interfaces present in the Integration Suite tenant that is configured in SM59 destination(SAP_PROXY_ESR)
    • In the Enterprise Service Browser view, navigate to Source --> ESR --> SWCs  to see the list of Integration Packages that contain atleast one of the proxy relevant artifacts(Datatypes,(Fault)Message Types,Service Interfaces) are listed.
    • Locate the Integration Package containing the desired Service Interface (Inbound or Outbound).
    • Drill down to Service Provider or Service Consumer.(Namespaces -->Choose the desire namespace -->Object Types)
    • Choose the Inbound (server proxy) or Outbound (client proxy) interface.
    • Right-click the selected Service Provider or Consumer ‚Üí choose Generate.
    • Proxy Generation Wizard opens. Provide:
    • Prefix for ABAP Class Names (if needed).
    • Package assignment (should be a transportable package, not $TMP if moving to QA/Prod).
    • Transport request for recording the generated objects.
    • The system creates ABAP proxy classes:
      • Inbound Server Proxy ‚Üí ABAP Class implementing the interface with predefined methods (developer writes business logic here).
      • Outbound Client Proxy ‚Üí ABAP Class to call external services (system generates methods to call the remote service).
      • Supporting DDIC structures, types, and message interfaces are also generated.
      • Save and Activate the generated proxies

Use the  generated proxy class to implement the Business logic  in Transaction SE80 or SE24 .

Current Limitations in the SPROXY Navigation Tree :

  • Folders are not visible in the SPROXY navigation tree
  • Datatype enhancements are not listed.
  • Classifications and Matching Service Interface details will be missing in the Proxy Editor of the Service Interface
  • ...

Recommended view to be used - Enterprise Services Browser view.

Also please ensure to import the service interfaces and its dependants to the Integration Suite tenant from the PI/PO ESR system that was earlier configured in SM 59 destination to be able to retain the already generated proxies. Try maintaining SWCV  to Integration Package mapping i.e. Avoid importing objects from multiple SWCV's to one Integration Packages.. Avoid having objects with same name and namespace in multiple Integration Packages.

entry.title: Re: Error 7000 while installing Integration services (B1if)
entry.content:
I reinstalled mine from the package B1IF10P_19-20009683.ZIP from SAP Download Center. I also found when searching the notes the following from SAP AI: 

Generated Answer
When installing the SAP Business One Integration Framework (B1if), issues may arise such as the installation rolling back without any errors or logs, particularly on Windows Server 2019 or 2022. To address this, it is recommended to manually install VC++ 2010 (x86/x64) before proceeding with the B1if installation. If the installation wizard closes unexpectedly during the process, reinstalling the B1if may resolve the issue. SAP plans to release feature packages or patches to address these problems, which will be available based on their discretion and the complexity of the implementation.
 
This helped my installation by installing the VC++2010 x64 for my Windows 2022 server, and it went through. Hope that helps.

entry.title: crystal report build. need to shed some lights!
entry.content:
Hi, 

This is for SAP Crystal Reports

we have below two scenarios in the system:

case scenario 1- we have part number ABC-12345 in line no.1 in the purchase order, received in ABC-12345, vouchered ABC-12345, added freight charge in line no.2 in invoice entry, maintenance fee in line no.3. 

case scenario 2- we have part number ABC-54321 in line no.1, freight charge in line no.2 in the purchase order, received in ABC-12345 and freight charge, vouchered ABC-12345 and freight charge.

we want to capture the cost plus overheads such as freight charge and maintenance fee all together for ABC-12345. we created a report for it, outer join receiver line no. to payable line no., but when we filter parts starting with "ABC's", the report also filter out all the overheads...it looks like payable line no. should be outer join something but i can't think about any related tables to link with.

we currently have purc_order_id and line no. from pur_order_line outer join receiver_line's purc_order_id and purc_order_line_no; purc_order_id from receiver_line inner join payable_line, purc_order_id and purc_order_line_no from receiver_line outer join payable_line; voucher_id from payable inner join voucher_id of payable_line.

Thank you!! @Chuma
